About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines Asian Japanese Japanese Ginger Pork 4.4 (56) 40 Reviews 13 Photos This recipe uses thinly sliced pork for a quick Japanese-style saut√©. It is excellent with rice and steamed veggies on the side. You can also double the recipe and use whole pork chops or chicken breasts for grilling. Submitted by baby23 Updated on April 3, 2025 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 13 13 13 13 Prep Time: 10 mins Cook Time: 10 mins Additional Time: 1 hr Total Time: 1 hr 20 mins Servings: 4 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 4 servings 2 tablespoons soy sauce 2 tablespoons sake 2 tablespoons mirin 1 tablespoon grated fresh ginger root 1 pound thinly sliced pork loin 3 tablespoons vegetable oil Directions Gather all ingredients. Brie Goldman / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco Mix together soy sauce, sake, mirin, and ginger in a large bowl until combined. Brie Goldman / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco Add sliced pork; stir to coat. Cover the bowl and marinate for about 1 hour. Brie Goldman / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco Heat oil in a large skillet or wok over high heat. Saut√© pork in hot oil until browned and cooked through; discard marinade. An instant-read thermometer inserted into pork should read at least 145 degrees F (63 degrees C). Brie Goldman / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco Recipe Tip Do not saut√© pork on low or medium heat; the juices will not cook fast enough to get a crispy texture. I‚Äôm sure it would be better with the little extra crisp of the frying. 05 of 13 Photo by¬† Barbara 11/09/2020 06 of 13 Photo by¬† Christopher Caldwell 10/03/2019 07 of 13 Photo by¬† Tara Laurens 03/29/2017 08 of 13 Photo by¬† donna m 05/06/2016 09 of 13 Photo by¬† LWM9181 02/01/2015 10 of 13 Photo by¬† OkinawanPrincess 10/25/2011 Excellent! I knew I would love this as I grew up eating dishes flavored with Mirin, Sake and ginger. I doubled the marinade and added a little more grated ginger. I marinated the pork loin for about 6 hours before saut√©ing. I saut√©ed the pork on high heat stirring and cooking until brown and meat looked crispy. I cooked the meat in three small batches, drained the grease, wiping the pan clean with paper towel before adding the next batch of meat. The kitchen quickly filled up with the aroma of this marinade. This was quick and easy with wonderful results! The pork was tender and flavorful infused with the succulent marinade. Mmmm. The ginger is pronounced but it is not overpowering.
